title: Method image_to_osd
body:
I have been using the the method **pytesseract.image_to_osd(img)** for detecting **orientation angles** of my images. It works fine for images rotated at angles 90,180, 270 and for upright(0deg) images. But if I pass an image lets say rotated at 45deg then I get this following error:

TesseractError: (1, 'Tesseract Open Source OCR Engine v5.0.0-alpha.20200328 with Leptonica Warning: Invalid resolution 0 dpi. Using 70 instead. Estimating resolution as 166 Warning. Invalid resolution 0 dpi. Using 70 instead. Too few characters. Skipping this page Error during processing.')

**Can I use this function for angles other than 0, 90, 270, 180?**
author: Prabh95

comments.body:
The OSD module is design to cope with pages rotated at angles 90,180, 270 degrees.

Tesseract can cope with a small skew of a few degrees. Skew of 45 degrees is too much for it, and it will fail to detect correctly all/most characters.

### Current Behavior:

author: Thimxx

comments.body:
I think this is outside the scope of tesseract, and the issue should be closed.

@stweil?

I think this is a (minor) bug.

When Tesseract fails to create a file (missing rights, disk full, or any other reason on any operating system), this should always be handled somehow in the code. In most cases at least a warning should be printed, other cases are fatal errors. We also have conditions where Tesseract creates a file, but terminates before writing to that file. I'd consider such empty files also as a bug.

So for this issue the code needs a fix. If a user sets `-c tessedit_write_images=1`, there should be either a valid output file or a warning message. I'll have a look and prepare a pull request.
@stweil : Will you prepare PR for before 4.0 release?
I don't think so if the release should be published in two weeks.
